Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A - Microfluidic Fungal Transformation System for Ultra High-Throughput Functional Genomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the Texas A&M University to develop an instrument based on microfluidic chips that enables ultra-fast genetic transformation and screening of fungi. Fungi play important roles, both beneficial and detrimental, in human life and in the earth's ecosystem. Rapidly improving molecular genetics and genomic technologies have allowed scientists to understand the inner workings of fungi and to utilize such information for making significant improvements in fungi-based bioproduction and mitigating fungal human and crop diseases. Despite this revolution in functional genomics, deleting or replacing genes in fungi is still the preferred method to unambiguously characterize their functions, a process that remains costly, time-consuming, and labor-intensive. The project is to develop an instrument that enables highly efficient genetic transformation of fungi using electric field and acoustic pressure, followed by rapid screening of the successfully transformed mutant strains using the latest microfluidic lab-on-a-chip technology. The developed instrument will be beta-tested by several fungal biology researchers and subsequently broadly disseminated through hands-on demonstrations at conferences and video journals.

This instrument is expected to revolutionize functional genomics research worldwide in both fungal biology and more broadly in microbiology by providing a streamlined gene-knockout instrument with orders-of-magnitude improvement in efficiency and cost savings. The instrument will also have significant long-term impacts on the agricultural and biotechnology industry. The proposed instrument development process requires close collaboration between engineers and microbiologists, and therefore will provide invaluable multidisciplinary research environment to train the next-generation of leaders in science and engineering. Notably, the project will also offer our post-docs, graduate students and undergraduates to engage in outreach activities aimed at high schools and the general public in the interest of communicating scientific research and exciting discoveries.

This award is being made jointly by two Programs- (1) Instrument Development for Biological Research, in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Biological Sciences Directorate), and (2) Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering, in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (Engineering Directorate).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungi play important roles, both beneficial and detrimental, in human life and in the earth’s ecosystem. To understand the role of the vast number of fungal species (over 1.5 million), function of individual genes and genome-wide genetic networks need to be experimentally tested and analyzed. And the best strategy to achieve this is to generate individual gene knockout mutants, and then compare their functions to the original strain. However, this is a very time- and labor-consuming procedure. Through this project a high-throughput microfluidic platform that allows rapid screening of successfully transformed fungi has been developed. The developed platform utilizes droplet microfluidics technology, where individual cells are encapsulated inside a pico-liter volume water-in-oil emulsion droplet, and then those that are potentially true knockout mutants are sorted for further off-chip analysis. Hundreds of thousands of such cell-encapsulated droplets can be generated, tested, and sorted, one droplet at a time (thus one cell at a time), within hours, reducing the time and effort needed by orders of magnitude compared to conventional assays. The developed platform was successfully tested in Fusarium species, the most devastating family of fungi in agricultural crop production worldwide. The project was performed by a multidisciplinary collaboration between a microfluidic system engineering laboratory and a fungal biology laboratory and provided cross-disciplinary training opportunities to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who worked together on this project. The training opportunity was also expanded to undergraduate students, who gained valuable experiences in working with the multidisciplinary team. Outcomes were also disseminated to the research community through journal publications and presentations at conferences.
